9787e28e-9334-4a99-9774-615cc7e64bf1.description: The American University Cybersecurity Professional Program in partnership with HackerU teaches students everything they need to defend digital information, implement security measures, respond to cyberattacks, and protect business and consumer data. The curriculum provides a comprehensive education in the fundamentals of cybersecurity through virtual lectures and participation in virtual cyber labs, real-world digital simulations, and individual and group exercises.
9787e28e-9334-4a99-9774-615cc7e64bf1.name: Cybersecurity Professional Program

badge_template_activities.title: Students complete a 400-hour program divided into an Introductory Course, Fundamental Courses, Cybersecurity Infrastructures Courses, and Advanced Cybersecurity Courses.

Introduction Course (30 Hours): The students learn to understand the fundamental principles of Cybersecurity and to have a grasp of basic technological concepts such as common operating systems, virtualization, communication over a computer network, and the cloud environment.

Fundamental Courses (135 hours): These essential courses provide the student with a foundational understanding of cybersecurity. The courses are Microsoft Security, Computer Networking, Cloud Security, Linux Security.

Cybersecurity Infrastructure Courses (100 Hours): The courses in this category lay the groundwork for a deeper understanding of the security measures and technologies cybersecurity professionals use every day. These courses provide essential expertise that prepares the student to enter the world of cybersecurity. Courses: Network Security, Cyber Infrastructure & Technology, Introduction to Python for Security.

Advanced Cybersecurity Courses (120 Hours): These courses prepare the student to address an attack that has already occurred, the advanced concepts in this category provide them with an understanding of different types of attacks, the attack kill chain, how to implement an attack, how to respond to an assault that is already underway, and how to mitigate it. The courses are: Offensive Security - Ethical Hacking, DFIR & Threat Hunting, Game Theory Strategy in Cybersecurity

Career Services 15 hours): Students receive career planning, training, and tools needed to enter the field of cybersecurity—along with personalized interview coaching, professional networking, internship placement assistance, and one-on-one consultations devoted to perfecting LinkedIn profiles and resumes.

Cyber Labs: Students learn to identify vulnerabilities on web, server, mobile, and desktop platforms and create secure defenses that protect against a variety of threats through immersive cyber labs and real-world simulations. This virtual hands-on environment provides students with the knowledge, training, and experience that make them a highly qualified candidate who is prepared to enter the field of cybersecurity

Certification Prep: The Cybersecurity Professional Program at American University prepares students for the following IT and cybersecurity certifications: CompTIA Network+, AWS Certified Cloud Practitioner, LPI Linux Essentials, Cisco Certified CyberOps Associate, CompTIA Security+, CompTIA CySA+

92752522-17d9-4283-8a42-0ee836a66a26.description: This course is an International Coaching Federation (ICF)-certified Accredited Coach Training Program (ACTP) designed for individuals who want to develop coaching skills and apply them to help achieve personal and organizational goals. It is ideal for anyone who seeks to become an Executive Coach or a leader who is interested in incorporating coaching into their leadership skills. Participants who complete the program meet the academic requirements to apply for their ICF credentials.
92752522-17d9-4283-8a42-0ee836a66a26.name: Leadership Coaching for Organizational Performance

badge_template_activities.title: This 132-hour International Coach Federation (ICF) certified Accredited Coach Training Program (ACTP) course divided into 12 full-day sessions, 10 video classes, self-recorded practice coaching sessions, outside classwork and a final exam.

Knowledge: During the course, the students Intricately understand coaching and coaching theory making them able to explain it in simple, intuitive terms. The students will also understand the requirements of 21st-century leadership and its implications.
Self-Mastery: This course will help students develop the cognitive, emotional, and body awareness required for self-mastery in becoming effective coaches.

Practice: Students record 6, 30-minute coaching sessions, which will be reviewed by a mentor coach. Feedback will be provided to the student as it relates to their application of the ICF Core Competencies.
Reinforcement: Students attend 7, 1-hour video conferences during the weeks that classes are not in session, which will complement and reinforce the theories and skills discussed during classes.

Assessment: The final exam will consist of a written open-book exam that will further students learning by demonstrating the practical application of their learning. A recorded coaching session will be submitted that will demonstrate the ability to apply the ICF Core Competencies at an ICF PCC level.  Upon passing the exam, a Certificate of Completion will be issued which can be submitted to the ICF when applying for their ACC and PCC certifications.

29015fab-97f9-4323-80ac-75377c0cbbc0.description: American University is proud to partner with Educators for Antiracism and issue this Digital Badge. 05b63199-eb6e-4038-9113-768f704c4114.description: This course introduces students to the concept of Culturally Responsive and Equitable Evaluation (CREE) by examining the history and underlying theories. In this course, students begin to assess their evaluation competencies and reflect on their evaluator identity, analyze the theories, and are introduced to the different approaches to CREE.
05b63199-eb6e-4038-9113-768f704c4114.name: SPEX-085 Leading Equitable Evaluation Through Theory

badge_template_activities.title: Discuss: Throughout the course the students engage in forum discussions on the topic of Culturally Responsive Equitable Evaluation.

Develop a Concept Map: In Week 1, The student will develop a concept map with their area of interest and its specific inequities as the first step for a final project. The students select an area of interest where they will frame their response to resistance as to why culturally responsive evaluation is important.
Self-Assess:  In Week 2, The students will complete a self-assessment to determine if their evaluation practice is culturally responsive and another self-assessment on their cultural identity.

Analyze: In Week 3, the student will analyze evaluations and describe how CREE could have been used. After identifying their area of interest and its inequities, the students will analyze their identity as an evaluator and review cases where CREE could have been applied.

Present: In Week 4, the students will advocate for CREE by creating a presentation and presenting it to their instructor and peers. Communicating results to stakeholders can make or break a research project. In this class, the student will practice communicating their results by presenting the project.

9c7387c0-a8b6-4802-aa1a-6db854973dde.description: This course equips students with the skills needed to conduct culturally responsive and equitable evaluation (CREE). The course introduces the methodology used to conduct a CREE and examines how to apply different methods to guide program improvement. It also explores how to use the results of CREE to inform community advocacy, decision-makers, and policy change that support equity and responsiveness.
9c7387c0-a8b6-4802-aa1a-6db854973dde.name: SPEX-086 Leading Equitable Evaluation Through Practice

badge_template_activities.title: Discuss: Throughout this course students critically analyze, synthesize, and evaluates the impact of structural and cultural factors (e.g. historical, social, economic, racial, ethnic, gender) on evaluation design and implementation.
Identify: In week 1, students identify, through focused reading, the framework, and methodology used to conduct CREE. They also reflect on what they have learned from the course.
Discuss: During week 2, the students discuss the impact of structural and cultural factors (e.g. historical, social, economic, racial, ethnic, gender) on evaluation design and implementation.
Select: In week 3, students, through research and discussion in data collection,  select the appropriate methods to conduct CREE.
Apply: In week 4, the students apply, through a presentation project, CREE approached to Evaluation.
